results.title: What is a fish
results.creator_credit: Michael Birch and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
Illustrates the major types of fish showing the anatomy of a typical fish, behaviour patterns such as commensalism, spawning, predation and territoriality.

results.title: What is a bird?
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
Describes the evolutionary relations between birds and reptiles. Shows the body structures of birds and explains how their structural characteristics help them to adapt to different environments. Also illustrates various patterns of behaviour. From the Series: Biology Program Unit 3, Animal Life.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.

results.title: Stinging-celled animals: coelenterates
results.creator_credit: Michael Birch and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
Describes the characteristics of the phylum coelenterata, showing physical structure and processes. Gives examples of fresh and salt water coelenterates. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Social insects: the honeybee
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
Shows how social insects live in colonies and divide into castes. Illustrates the particular adaptation of the various castes in relation to reproduction, populatin control and food gathering. Shows the metamorphosis of a honey-bee from egg to adult.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
Shows how social insects live in colonies and divide into castes. Illustrates the particular adaptation of the various castes in relation to reproduction, populatin control and food gathering. Shows the metamorphosis of a honey-bee from egg to adult.

results.title: The Single-celled animals: protozoa
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
This film illustrates the characteristics and behaviour of representatives of each class of protozoans. It demonstrates the processes of digestion and reproduction, and discusses theories of protozoan evolution from ancient single-celled plants. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films

results.title: Segmentation: the annelid worms
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program. Unit 3. Animal life”

Describes the structure and functions of the nervous, digestive and reproductive systems of the earthworm. Shows that the segmented annelid worm body represents an important evolutionary development.
Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The Jointed-legged animals: arthropods
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
This film shows the jointed-legged animals and the structural and functional characteristics of animals in the phylum arthropoda: examples from each of the five classes, and their evolutionary development. Metamorphosis and moulting processes are illustrated using photo-micrography and time-lapse photography. The economic importance to man is discussed. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
This film shows the jointed-legged animals and the structural and functional characteristics of animals in the phylum arthropoda: examples from each of the five classes, and their evolutionary development. Metamorphosis and moulting processes are illustrated using photo-micrography and time-lapse photography. The economic importance to man is discussed. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Flatworms: platyhelminthes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
After brief views of land, fresh water, marine and parasitic flatworms, shows the important characteristics of the common planaria. These are the simplest animals with bilateral symmetry, a distinct head, a central nervous system and a substantially developed mesoderm layer. Their regenerative ability is demonstrated, showing polarity, the anterior-posterior gradient and cell dominance.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.

results.title: Fish embryo from fertilization to hatching
results.creator_credit: J.V. Durden, Sidney Goldsmith and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
Illustrates how fish eggs are fertilised in a stream, then traces the development of the zygote from the first cell cleavage to the formation of a young fish. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The First many-celled animals: sponges
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
Demonstrates that the sponge represents one development of multicellularity in animals. Shows life processes and the adaptation of sponges to their environment. Suitable for upper secondary level.
